column3: All installed costs incurred prior to commercial operations date (COD). CapEx components include turbine, BOS, and soft costs.
Converts kinetic energy from wind into three phase AC electrical energy.
Main power conversion system in the wind turbine, where energy captured by the rotor is transferred  to drive the generator via the main shaft system, with or without a gearbox
Provides speed and torque conversion between the rotor and the generator.  Only applicable for geared designs.
Planet carrier, planet gear, ring gear, sun gear, spur gear, hollow shaft
Planet bearing, carrier bearing, shaft bearing
Bushing, case, mounting, torque arm system
Debris sensors, oil level sensors, pressure 1 & pressure 2 sensors, and temperature sensor
Primary filter, secondary filter, primary motor, primary pump, hose/fitting, seal, and reservoir
Pump, radiator, hoses
Converts mechanical energy to electrical energy.
Hoses, filter, cooling fan, motor, radiator
Pump, pump motor, reservoir
Commentator, exciter, resistance controller, rotor lamination, rotor winding, slip ring, rotor magnets, brush
Core temperature sensor, encoder, watt meter
Stator magnets, stator lamination, stator windings
Front bearing, rear bearing, silent block, housing, and shaft

column2: Low Speed Shaft and Main Bearing System
column3: Transfers torque from the rotor to the gearbox (if applicable) or generator if dirrect drive
Low speed shaft, compression coupling, rotor lock, connector plate, and slip ring assembly
Main bearing upwind, main bearing downwind, main bearing seals,
Main bearing temperature sensor, low speed shaft rpm, and position sensor

column2: High Speed Shaft and Braking System
column3: High speed shaft, coupling, rotor lock, and transmission shaft
High speed shaft, coupling, rotor lock, and transmission shaft
Brake disc, brake calipers, brake pads, and transmission lock
High speed shaft rpm sensor, position sensor
System to capture wind energy and transfer to the drive train (through the low speed shaft).
Captures the kinetic energy in the wind and transfer torque and other unwanted loads to the drive train module and rest of the turbine.
Interface between the main composite section of the blade and the blade bearing
Low-density core material between laminates
Spar cap and spar web
Bonds for leading edge and trailing edge
T-bolt/Root Insert, others
Internal structural laminates and skin laminates
Coatings to protect from erosion
Termination and down-conductor
Sensors, heaters, wiring, thermal conductors
Active and passive blade accessories: aileron, tip bakes, etc.
Adjusts the pitch angle of the blades to control power output from the turbine, minimize loads, and start/stop turbine as needed. Blades are attached to the hub through the pitch systems

Motor, motor cooling fan, pitch bearing, motor brake, pitch gear, gear reducer, pinion, power electronics/drive, cabling, contractor/circuit breaker fuse, encoder, power supply, heater, accumulator, pump
Switchboard/limit switch, battery, battery charger, heater, position controller, load controller
Temperature sensor, voltmeter, position sensor
Seals, auto lube system, pitch cylinder linkage, bushing, proportional valve, hose/fitting
The hub connects the blades and pitch system to the low speed shaft within the drivetrain module
Connects the blades and pitch system to the low speed shaft within the drivetrain module
Protective cap fitted on the hub, largely aesthetic
Provides  access to and exit from the hub system
Power off-take system for the wind turbine,  connects the drivetrain module to the array cable system through the main transformer in the tower
Coverts variable frequency from asynchronous generator to grid-compliant power of the right ‘quality' and with a stable frequency of either 50 Hz or 60 Hz

Power supply, cabinet, heating system, cabinet sensor, communication & interface unit, control board, generator side fan, grid side fan, measurement unit, power supply, power supply 24 V, tachometer adapter, thermostat
Branching unit, capacitors, contactors, generator side converter, generator side power module, grid side converter, grid side power module, inductor, load switch, pre-charge unit
Common mode filter, crowbar system, DC chopper, generator side filter, line filter assembly, voltage limit unit
System to covert generator voltage to array cable system voltage for collection

IGBT module, rectifier bridge, crowbar system, driver/control board, cables, machine contractor, Mv Busbar/Isolator/Circuit Breaker, Mv Switchgear/Disconnect, motor contractor, soft starter, grounding system
Main transformer within tower, nacelle-mounted transformer
Equipment to measure the function of the power electric system
Connects the wind turbines with an onshore operations center, provides wind project operator with information about the status of wind turbine systems and allows remote control of some functions
Rotor controller, nacelle controller, tower controller (all comprised of numerous level 6 components)
Analog I/O unit, digital I/O unit, Ethernet module, field bus master, field bus slave, frequency unit, controller internal communication system
Sensors, cables, data logger, protocol adapter card for data logger
Cables, connectors, contactor/circuit breaker fuse
Other equipment necessary for the function of the electrical system
Cables to off-take power from drivetrain and transport to main transformer (in tower base)

24 DC feeder, auxiliary transformer, breaker, cabinet, fan, fuse, grid protection relay, light, mechanical switch, power point/supply, protection cabinet, push button, relay, space heater, surge arrester, thermal protection, UPS
Air termination, bonding element, earth connector & termination, sliding contact, spark gap system, surge arrester
Activities performed by manufacturer to integrate, assemble, test, and verify the electrical module before delivery to customer (does not include commissioning activities)

Nacelle module provides structural interface between tower module, drivetrain module, and rotor module. Provides shelter to sensitive electrical and mechanical components and equipment for access by maintenance personnel.
Nacelle structure provides the structure interface between the tower,  drivetrain, and rotor and shelters sensitive equipment
Structure, Exit hatch, hatch, latches, and helicopter landing pad.
Bedplate generator frame  (can be a single unit), including welded steel and fasteners
Coatings to protect from corrosion in marine environment
Other equipment within the nacelle necessary for the necessary for the function of the wind turbine
Anemometer, wind vane, temperature sensor
Nacelle heater, nacelle vent, nacelle lighting
Navigational lighting lights (requirements set by FAA in United States)
Cat walks, cables, ladders, landing, people hatch, crane hatch,
Tie-off system, firefighting system, fall arrester, down conductor, service crate, beacon, nacelle cover metallic mesh, lighting protection
Davit crane to lift small components (<2 mt) from support structure or maintenance vessel into nacelle
Hoist within the tower used to hoist tools and supplies during maintenance activities
Yaw system orients the nacelle to the wind direction during operation.
Yaw brake calipers, disc, path, hoses
Motor, gear, pinion, bearing, damper
Accumulator, pump, hoses and valves, motor
Wind-up counter, yaw encoder, position sensor
Activities performed by manufacturer to integrate, assemble, test, and verify the Nacelle module before delivery to customer (does not include commissioning activities)
Support structure element that connects the nacelle, drive train and rotor modules with the substructure & foundation, can house electrical conversion equipment and provide emergency shelter
Tower system is the primary structural component
Tower sections, generally consists of rolled steel sections though other options are being considered
Coatings to protect from corrosion in marine environment
Other equipment within the tower necessary for the necessary for the function of the wind turbine
Climb assist, hatches, ladders, landings, lighting, doors, food and fresh water storage,
Wiring to support tower auxiliaries
Lighting within the tower to provide a safe working environment
Passive accessories on tower to improve energy capture (likely applicable only for downwind deigns)
Tower mounted damping system to reduce transfer of unwanted torque from nacelle through tower
Activities performed by manufacturer to integrate, assemble, test, and verify the Tower Module before  delivery to customer  (does not include commissioning activities)
Financial costs for wind turbine supply contract, including warranty cost, G&A expenses, and profit margin
Expected costs of providing guarantee that turbine will operate above a set availability and that power production matches or exceeds advertised power curve for a fixed period
Profit margin on sale of wind turbine equipment and warranty
Overhead for supplying turbine including administrative salaries and benefits, rent, utilities, depreciation, insurance, etc.
Transportation of all turbine modules to the staging port.
Transportation of drivetrain and nacelle from the manufacturing facility to the staging site.
Transportation of the rotor module from the manufacturing facility  to the staging site.
Transportation of the tower module from the manufacturing facility  to the staging site.
Process of assuring that all wind turbine systems and components are operational through predefined series of tests and checks.
Balance of equipment, labor, and material costs (other than wind turbine) incurred prior to COD
All activities from project inception to financial close (where financial close is the date where project and financing agreements have been signed and all the required conditions  have been met)
Acquisition of permits and leases required for site assessment, construction, and operation at the project site
Initial desktop-level studies to select project location, develop a conceptual design, identify regulatory requirements, and create preliminary business case
Environmental and social surveys/studies required by regulators or otherwise necessary for the project.
Activities necessary to obtain permits from relevant authorities
Activities necessary to obtain commercial or research lease to operate the project from relevant authorities
Stakeholder education, marketing, and other efforts to facilitate public acceptance of a project
Legal support, external consulants, accounting, etc, during development
Engineering studies to specify the design of the project (e.g., technology, layout) and understand economics and risks associated with the design
Preliminary engineering design studies to develop general design of project, identify a short list of technologies for further evaluation, and identify fatal flaws

Engineering activities to develop final design specification, address areas of risk/uncertainty, determine technical & economic feasibility, and develop  necessary specifications to begin procurement process
Review by 3rd party, ind. verification agent to assess feasibility of design basis, resulting in Certification Report

Equipment, material and labor costs required for collecting/analysis of wind resource, ocean conditions, and geological data at project site. Defines parameters for engineering assessments as data becomes available
meteorological tower including substructure (fixed or floating), instrumentation (meteorological and oceanographic), and data acquisition system
Vessels, labor, and equipment required to install met station, instrumentation and data acquisition system

Collection, cleaning, analysis of data to develop wind resource profile and power production estimates for a selection of turbine types at project site. Might include array layout optimization surveys
Equipment (benthic node, buoys) and installation costs for characterization of ocean conditions (e.g., currents)

Vessels, labor, and equipment required to establish bathymetry, sea bed features, water depth, stratigraphy, and identify hazards on seafloor. Performed for project site and potential cable routes to interconnection
Activities to gain access to the transmission grid and negotiate contracts to sell or otherwise market  power

Activities required to obtain a Large Generator Interconnection Agreement from FERC, prepared in coordination with transmission system operator. Studies cover technical considerations of interconnecting project with grid, while maintaining system balance and within grid operating limits
Costs of obtaining or expanding transmission rights of way for any onshore electric infrastructure (e.g., overhead transmission lines), includes any costs to permit onshore transmission
Efforts to develop power marketing strategy, forecast pricing, and negotiate Power Purchase Agreements
Project Management from the start of the Development Phase through Financial Close
Preparation of tenders for each work package, evaluation of bids, negotiations with suppliers
Salaries for management and support staff on payroll of developer, some overlap with categories above is expected, depending on amount of work that is completed internally vs. contracted
Overhead for the project company including administrative salaries and benefits, rent, utilities, depreciation, insurance, etc.
Any margin earned by the developer upon sale of the project at financial close, does not include the cost to a new owner of any stake that a developer might retain in the  project
Efforts to arrange and secure equity and/or non-recourse debt facilities at the project level

Activities performed by potential investors to investigate technical and economic aspects of the project and estimate value prior to executing a financial commitment. Typically conducted by 3rd party technical consultant hired by investor
Administrative costs incurred by investors (debt and equity) during the evaluation of the investment
Developer's legal support to during negotiations to arrange financing
Construction Management refers to management activities from Financial Close through COD
Project Management from Financial Close through  COD
Salaries for management and support staff on payroll of project owner and/or construction manager
Overhead for the project company  and/or construction manager including administrative salaries and benefits, rent, utilities, depreciation, insurance, etc
Any margin earned by an independent construction management firm

Review by a 3rd party, independent verification agent to assure that project is in compliance with design basis as well as technical standards and regulatory requirements, results in Project Certificate
Coordination and monitoring to ensure compliance with HSE requirements during construction
Coordination and monitoring to ensure compliance with health and safety requirements during construction
Coordination and monitoring to ensure compliance with environmental requirement during construction
Activities and physical aspects of a staging port; elements needed to support the delivery, storage, handling, and deployment of offshore wind farm components
Port facilities or space leased to support the installation of the project
Leased space at staging port to store turbine components and foundations
Leased space at staging port with high load bearing capacity to perform onshore assembly activities
Workshops to support fabrication, construction or assembly of components
Cranage fees to use and operate crawler cranes, tower cranes, self-propelled modular transporters (SMPTs) used for land-based assembly of components and load out onto installation vessels
Any improvement to existing port infrastructure paid for by project owner (e.g., quayside reinforcement)
Fees for vessel access, docking and loading/unloading
Charges levied upon entry of vessels into the port, generally calculated on standard formula basis upon Gross Registered Ton (GRT)
Charges levied for the use of a berth either occupied by a vessel or by pre-assembly activities
Charges for loading or unloading cargo from vessels, generally calculated by tonnage and equipment requirements for loading/unloading the cargo
All elements of offshore wind turbine support structure below point of connection with tower
Main structural interface that transfers loads into seabed
Steel pipes driven into seabed to provide support and transfer loads acting on structure into seabed
Anchors are installed below mudline and transfer loads from floating platforms into the seabed
Chain, wire, or synthetic fiber ropes to connect floating platforms with anchors on the seabed
Connectors required to attach the mooring lines/tendons to anchors and to the platform
Ancillary equipment used during the installation of the mooring system
Main structure that connects the foundation to the tower
Structural steel or concrete (e.g., jacket, tripod, floating platform, gravity base)
Main structural interface between the primary structure and point of connection with the tower
Hardware to secure connections between substructure & foundation elements
Grout and ancillary equipment to secure connections between substructure & foundation elements
Anti-corrosion marine coatings applied to substructure elements
Additional non-structural elements attached to substructure elements
Provides interface between maintenance vessels and substructure to enable safe personnel access
Provides access to the inside of the turbine and a work platform for maintenance
Routes array cable from trench to point of connection with turbine, protects cable from dynamic loads
Provides access from the vessel landing to the deck
Encloses the deck to provide a safe working environment for personnel
Anti-corrosion marine coatings applied to any outfitting steel elements

Davit crane installed on deck to lift small components, used for maintenance
Equipment installed on vessel landing, ladders, and deck to facilitate safe access to turbine
Ballast to control draft/stability of floating systems, ballast can be fixed or variable (active or passive)
Systems to monitor and control substructure systems (e.g., variable ballast)
Rock fill or concrete mattresses to protect substructures from scouring (caused by currents)

Cost to transport substructure and foundation elements from manufacturer to staging port
Process of assuring that all substructure & foundation systems and components are operational through a predefined series of tests and checks.
Collects power generated by the turbines and transports to the offshore substation

Equipment and materials used to protect cable from damage (strikes, overbending, etc.)

Concrete, sand bags, polyurethane mats to route cables over existing electric/telecommunications cables
Protective sheath that can be fitted around cables where burial is not an option
Used to seal the ends of the J-Tube and keep sea water out, can be active or passive
Prevents the overbending of static cables during installation and operations
Limit bending stresses and maintain acceptable curvature for dynamic cables at hang off point and touch down

Transports power from offshore substation to point of connection with onshore electric infrastructure (landfall point)

Prevents the overbending of static cables during installation and operations

Other purchases necessary for the operation of the wind project after COD. Examples include: safety equipment (e.g., harnesses, floatation devices), equipment to store replacement parts (e.g., climate control for spare electric cables), vehicles to support operations (e.g., fork trucks)

Assembly and installation activities conducted at the staging port and at the project site. Assume that financial costs related to warranties, contractor insurance, SG&A, profit margin, etc, are loaded in day rates for vessels, labor, and equipment

Financial expenditures for which the project owner is responsible prior to COD, related to either payments for financial products, carrying charges on loans, or setting up financial instruments

Insurance policies held by owner during construction period, can include construction all risk, marine cargo, commercial general liability, workers compensation, environmental site liability, pollution liability, etc. Does not include insurance held by contractors
Financial vehicle to cover the anticipated costs of decommissioning the project at end of operational life
Payments into reserve accounts set up to cover major maintenance expenditures (MRA) and debt service (DSRA), often required by debt finance providers

Liquid financial instrument set up to respond to ‘known unknown’ costs that arise during construction, does not include contingences set by manufactures and contractors as part of supply contract pricing
Carrying charges of expenditures on equipment and services incurred before COD
Expenditures required to operate the project and maintain availability, generally annualized
Vessel, labor, and equipment costs of operations for the project

Annualized cost of a contract, generally between the owner and turbine OEM or Third Party, to maintain the offshore wind project at a guaranteed level of availability for a defined period, will likely replace scheduled and unscheduled maintenance categories below for duration of contract

Activities to ensure that Turbine systems are operating correctly and to minimize unscheduled breakdowns/ downtime, includes cost of vessels, labor, equipment, spare parts and consumables. Also known as preventative maintenance
Activities to respond to random failures of turbine equipment including costs of vessels, labor, equipment, replacement parts, and consumables
Unscheduled maintenance related to Drivetrain Modules
Unscheduled maintenance related to Electric Modules
Unscheduled maintenance related to Rotor Modules
Unscheduled maintenance related to Nacelle Modules
Unscheduled maintenance related to Tower Modules

Activities to ensure that BOS systems are operating correctly and to minimize unscheduled breakdowns/ downtime, includes cost of vessels, labor, equipment, spare parts and consumables.  Also known as preventative maintenance
Activities to respond to random failures of BOS equipment including costs of vessels, labor, equipment, replacement parts, and consumables
Unscheduled maintenance related to Substructure & Foundations
Unscheduled maintenance related to Array Cable System
Unscheduled maintenance related to Export Cable System
Unscheduled maintenance related to Offshore Substation
Unscheduled maintenance related to Onshore Electric Infrastructure
Unscheduled maintenance related to Other Infrastructure
Operations: non-equipment costs of operations for the project
Payments to regulatory body for permission to operate at project site, terms defined within lease
Project Management from COD to up until decommissioning
Salaries for management and support staff on payroll of project owner and/or operations manager
Overhead for the project company  and/or operations manager including administrative salaries and benefits, rent, utilities, depreciation, insurance, etc.
Any margin earned by an independent operations management company
Any payments to Transmissions Systems Operators or Transmission Asset Owners for rights to transport generated power.

Costs of leasing equipment and facilities to support operations. Could include expenditures for warehouse, fork trucks, etc after COD.

Coordination and monitoring to ensure compliance with health and safety requirements during operations
